oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Influences on Early Fetal Loss in Dairy Cattle
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Moore, Dale A.
Overton, Michael W.
Truscott, Marla L.
Chebel, Ricardo
BonDurant, Robert H.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: repeat breeding
fertilization rate
early fetal loss
artificial insemination
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Early fetal loss in dairy cattle is a major factor contributing to repeat breeding. If the average fertilization rate in cattle is 85-95% and the incidence of repeat breeders is 56-72% of the herd, then embryonic or early fetal loss (EFL) accounts for 15-25% wastage. It was the purpose of this project to evaluate the effects that changes in body condition score (BCS) and breeding a potentially pregnant cow have on EFL during two periods: between 24-28 days after artificial insemination (AI), and between 28-42 days after AI.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: American Association of Bovine Practitioners Conference Proceedings; 2003; 159
